prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Custom Mosaic-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SG for the western half of the custom elliptic mosaic field. The thecnical justification is identical as that of SG2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use a spectral resolution bandwidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity estimate, because the velocity width of our target is known to be 10-50 km/s in FWHM (Montero-Castano 2009).
We assume the typical intensity of the target line to be 0.26 Jy/beam (or 0.7K) for the 2 pc-ring of the CND, as justified below. From single dish observations with the ASTE 10 m telescope, the [CI] 3P1-3P0 to HCN J=4-3 brightness temperature ratio is measured to be ~1 for the CND. Considering a possibility that the [CI] line is more spatially extended and more flux is resolved-out, we assume the [CI] 3P1-3P0 to HCN J=4-3 ratio to be 0.5 in brightness temperature scale for the ALMA observation, corresponding to a flux density ratio of 1. The synthesis observation by Montero-Castano (2009) detected HCN J=4-3 emission with 2 Jy/beam (4".6 x 3".0 beamsize) for wide spatial range. Therefore we expect the [CI] intensity within the resolution beamwidth of the 12-m array (1".36) to be 0.26 Jy/beam on average. We define the sensitivity requirement to be 52 mJy per single pointing, i.e., 1/5 of the above typical peak intensity. We perform a Nyquist-sampled mosaic, which improves the sensitivity by 1.58 and hence allows 8-sigma detection for the all known feature in the CND. This corresponds to a 5-sigma column density detection limit of 5e20 cm^-2 for a velocity width of 10km/s, and a mass detection limit of 0.05 Msun within the 12-m Array beam, which would be sufficient to search for molecular clouds inside the CND.
The emission may suffer more missing flux for the v_LSR range from 0 to 60 km/s, where the emission from CND overlaps with the extended emission in the background and foreground, but we may expect the missing flux is satisfactorily recovered by the ACA.
Continuum basebands are observed in order to maximize the outcome of the observation, for which we do not define strict sensitivity requirement. The peak continuum flux density of 20 mJy is estimated from the Herschel 350micron data, by correcting for the frequency difference and the beam filling factor.

We request the 1875 MHz bandwidth mode for the correlator setup, which offers velocity resolution of 0.595 km/s and velocity coverage of 1142 km/s. This is sufficient to cover the full velocity distribution of the neutral and ionized gas in the observed regions, namely, -300 km/s to +300 km/s. The velocity resolution is chosen so that we can resolve the known spectral features of 10 km/s velocity widths and possibly existing quiescent cores, whose typical velocity width is 1 km/s.

There is no available synthesis imaging data of 500 GHz [CI] line toward the Galactic center, and its spatial distribution and intensity is unknown. Therefore, as the first attempt of imaging of this line, we will observe the largest spatial structure possible with the ALMA spec. We request a spatial resolution of 1.36 arcsec, i.e., twice the synthesized beamsize with the most compact 12-m Array configuration. The smallest structure of the target detected with the previous observations (including ALMA data) is of 1 arcsec scale, and hence our resolution requirement is sufficiently high to detect all known molecular cloud features.
The size of the CND is 2 pc, corresponding to 50" in angular scale. The largest angular scale of 7" is, however, chosen so that the observation does not require the TP array. Our CMZ survey in the [CI] line is now under way by using the ASTE 10-m telescope, with which we can obtain a high-quality single-dish image of the target with a 15" resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Custom Mosaic-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SG for the eastern half of the custom elliptic mosaic field. The thecnical justification is identical as that of SG1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use a spectral resolution bandwidth of 5 km/s for the sensitivity estimate, because the velocity width of our target is known to be 10-50 km/s in FWHM (Montero-Castano 2009).
We assume the typical intensity of the target line to be 0.26 Jy/beam (or 0.7K) for the 2 pc-ring of the CND, as justified below. From single dish observations with the ASTE 10 m telescope, the [CI] 3P1-3P0 to HCN J=4-3 brightness temperature ratio is measured to be ~1 for the CND. Considering a possibility that the [CI] line is more spatially extended and more flux is resolved-out, we assume the [CI] 3P1-3P0 to HCN J=4-3 ratio to be 0.5 in brightness temperature scale for the ALMA observation, corresponding to a flux density ratio of 1. The synthesis observation by Montero-Castano (2009) detected HCN J=4-3 emission with 2 Jy/beam (4".6 x 3".0 beamsize) for wide spatial range. Therefore we expect the [CI] intensity within the resolution beamwidth of the 12-m array (1".36) to be 0.26 Jy/beam on average. We define the sensitivity requirement to be 52 mJy per single pointing, i.e., 1/5 of the above typical peak intensity. We perform a Nyquist-sampled mosaic, which improves the sensitivity by 1.58 and hence allows 8-sigma detection for the all known feature in the CND. This corresponds to a 5-sigma column density detection limit of 5e20 cm^-2 for a velocity width of 10km/s, and a mass detection limit of 0.05 Msun within the 12-m Array beam, which would be sufficient to search for molecular clouds inside the CND.
The emission may suffer more missing flux for the v_LSR range from 0 to 60 km/s, where the emission from CND overlaps with the extended emission in the background and foreground, but we may expect the missing flux is satisfactorily recovered by the ACA.
Continuum basebands are observed in order to maximize the outcome of the observation, for which we do not define strict sensitivity requirement. The peak continuum flux density of 20 mJy is estimated from the Herschel 350micron data, by correcting for the frequency difference and the beam filling factor.

We request the 1875 MHz bandwidth mode for the correlator setup, which offers velocity resolution of 0.595 km/s and velocity coverage of 1142 km/s. This is sufficient to cover the full velocity distribution of the neutral and ionized gas in the observed regions, namely, -300 km/s to +300 km/s. The velocity resolution is chosen so that we can resolve the known spectral features of 10 km/s velocity widths and possibly existing quiescent cores, whose typical velocity width is 1 km/s.

There is no available synthesis imaging data of 500 GHz [CI] line toward the Galactic center, and its spatial distribution and intensity is unknown. Therefore, as the first attempt of imaging of this line, we will observe the largest spatial structure possible with the ALMA spec. We request a spatial resolution of 1.36 arcsec, i.e., twice the synthesized beamsize with the most compact 12-m Array configuration. The smallest structure of the target detected with the previous observations (including ALMA data) is of 1 arcsec scale, and hence our resolution requirement is sufficiently high to detect all known molecular cloud features.
The size of the CND is 2 pc, corresponding to 50" in angular scale. The largest angular scale of 7" is, however, chosen so that the observation does not require the TP array. Our CMZ survey in the [CI] line is now under way by using the ASTE 10-m telescope, with which we can obtain a high-quality single-dish image of the target with a 15" resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Increasing evidence for star formation in the circumnuclear region of the Milky Way has been reported, despite the hostile environment for star formation. Meanwhile, complete knowledge about the distribution and kinematics of the molecular gas in the central parsecs is hampered by the extreme physical condition there, where the most commonly-used molecular mass tracers, namely CO rotational lines, might function less efficiently. One biggest mystery is how much molecular gas are present there and how the stars can form against the strong tidal field created by the nucleus, to which the answer remains unsettled. Our recent observations of the atomic carbon (C^0) [CI] line have found evidence for the atomic carbon dominates the carbon-bearing species in the central few pc region, whose relative abundance to CO exceeds unity, invoking a speculation that the molecular mass there are occupied by CO-dark mass. We propose a [CI] imaging of the central 5 parsec region of the Galactic center, to delineate the molecular mass distribution and thereby investigate the star formation activity in the innermost region of the Milky Way.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University
